{{short description|Australian journalist}} '''Ulrich Ruegg Ellis''' (23 July 1904 – 4 December 1981) was an Australian journalist, political activist, and historian. He was known for his work in developing [[Canberra]], his involvement with the [[Proposals for new Australian States|New State Movement]], and his behind-the-scenes work with the [[National Party of Australia|Country Party]]. He was the younger brother of the writer [[Malcolm Henry Ellis]].
==Early life== Ellis was born in [[Mount Morgan, Queensland]], the youngest child of Constance Jane (née Ruegg) and Thomas James Ellis. His father was an Irish-born miner and his mother was born in England. He was raised solely by his mother from the age of three, when she and the children moved to the [[Brisbane]] suburb of [[Tingalpa, Queensland|Tingalpa]]. Ellis attended the local state school in [[Kelvin Grove, Queensland|Kelvin Grove]] before going on to [[Brisbane Grammar School]]. He became a cadet journalist at the age of 16.<ref name=adb>{{cite news|url=http://adb.anu.edu.au/biography/ellis-ulrich-ruegg-12459|title=Ellis, Ulrich Ruegg (1904–1981)|publisher=''[[Australian Dictionary of Biography]]''|author=Andrew Moore|year=2007}}</ref>
==Journalism and life in Canberra== From 1921 to 1922, Ellis worked in [[Melbourne]] as a member of a news agency serving regional newspapers. He later worked for metropolitan daily newspapers, and then in 1925 began writing for the ''Morning Post'', the newspaper of the [[Country Party (Victoria)|Victorian Country Party]]. Ellis moved to [[Canberra]] in 1927 as one of the first permanent press correspondents; he was one of the forerunners of the [[Canberra Press Gallery]]. He married Ray Arnot Maxwell, the daughter of federal MP [[George Maxwell (Australian politician)|George Maxwell]], on 19 December 1930. Ellis was a "passionate advocate of local self-government" for Canberra and an advocate for the improvement of the capital's amenities, which were those of a small country town. He was the inaugural chairman of the Canberra Tourist Bureau from 1937 to 1940, and served on the [[Australian Capital Territory Advisory Council]], an elective office, from 1947 to 1951.<ref name=adb/>
In 1936, Ellis began working for the [[Department of Commerce (Australia)|Department of Commerce]] as a commercial intelligence officer. He moved to Melbourne in 1940 and joined the [[Department of Munitions]] in an administrative capacity overseeing 600 employees. In 1944, Ellis moved back to Canberra and joined the [[Department of Post-War Reconstruction]] as deputy director of public relations.<ref name=adb/> He wrote a letter to ''[[The Canberra Times]]'' in April 1945 criticising Interior Minister [[Joe Collings]], accusing him of "laugh[ing] with contempt in the face of the common principles of administrative justice" and calling him "unfit to administer his Department". He was subsequently charged under the Public Service Act and fined ₤2 for contravening regulations.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.smh.com.au/opinion/australian-public-service-commissions-new-social-media-guidelines-go-too-far-20170810-gxtj7l.html|title=Australian Public Service Commission's new social media guidelines go too far|publisher=''[[The Sydney Morning Herald]]''|date=10 August 2017|access-date=15 November 2018|author=Paul Malone}}</ref> Ellis's final public-service position was in the [[Department of Information (Australia)|Department of Information]] from 1946 to 1947. He subsequently established a rural lobby group, the Office of Rural Research.<ref name=adb/>
==Politics== In 1928, Ellis was appointed private secretary to [[Earle Page]], the leader of the [[National Party of Australia|Country Party]]. They became close friends, and Ellis shared Page's passion for the New State Movement, which advocated for the creation of new states in regional [[New South Wales]] and [[Queensland]]. In 1933, Ellis served as the publicity officer for [[Charles Hardy (Australian politician)|Charles Hardy]]'s Riverina Movement, which advocated the secession of the [[Riverina]] from the rest of New South Wales. The following year, he gave evidence before the New South Wales [[royal commission]] on new states, chaired by Judge [[Harold Sprent Nicholas]]. Ellis served on the executive of the [[New England New State Movement]] from 1948, and he and his wife moved to [[Armidale, New South Wales]], in 1960. He campaigned for the "Yes" vote in the 1967 New England secession referendum, which failed.<ref name=adb/>
During the 1950s, Ellis served as "publicist, valet, chauffeur, nursemaid and baggage handler" to [[Arthur Fadden]], the leader of the Country Party and Deputy Prime Minister. He published two histories of the Country Party: ''The Country Party: A Political and Social History of the Party in New South Wales'' (1958), and ''A History of the Australian Country Party'' (1963).<ref name=adb/>

'''Vasil Kanchov''' ({{lang-bg|Васил Кънчов}} ''Vasil Kǎnčov'') (26 July 1862 – 6 February 1902) was a [[Bulgaria]]n [[geographer]], [[ethnographer]] and [[politician]].
== Biography == [[Image:BASA-2072K-1-408-15-Vasil Kanchov.JPG|right|thumb|Vasil Kanchov]] Vasil Kanchov was born in [[Vratsa]]. Upon graduating from High school in [[Lom, Bulgaria|Lom]], Bulgaria, he entered the University of [[Kharkiv|Harkov]], then in [[Russia]]. During the [[Serbo-Bulgarian War]] 1885 he suspended his education and took part in the war. Later, he went on to pursue studies at universities in [[Munich]] and [[Stuttgart]], but in 1888 he interrupted his education again due to an illness.
In the following years Kanchov was a Bulgarian teacher in [[Macedonia (region)|Macedonia]]. He was a teacher in the [[Bulgarian Men's High School of Thessaloniki]] (1888–1891), a director of Bulgarian schools in [[Serres, Greece|Serres]] district (1891–1892), a headmaster of Bulgarian Men's High School of [[Thessaloniki]] (1892–1893), а chief school inspector of the Bulgarian schools in Macedonia (1894–1897).
After 1898 Kanchov returned to Bulgaria and went into politics. In the beginning of 1902 he became an educational minister of Bulgaria, but was killed in his office by a psychopath.
He travelled extensively after 1888, visiting and researching all over Macedonia.
==Works== *''Macedonia — ethnography and statistics'' 1900 ([http://www.promacedonia.org/vk/index.html "Македония. Етнография и статистика"']). *''[[s:en:Orohydrography of Macedonia|Orohydrography of Macedonia]]'' 1911 ("Орохидрография на Македония"). *''The region of Bitola, Prespa and Ohrid. Travel notes.''. 1890 ("Битолско, Преспа и Охридско. Пътни бележки"). *''The present and the past of the town of Veles''. 1892 ("Сегашното и недавнашното минало на гр. Велес").
==Honours== [[Kanchov Peak]] on [[Loubet Coast]], [[Antarctica]] is named after Vasil Kanchov.
